div.head: TO THE RIGHT VERtuous renowned, and for angel like rule ouer their owne passible tender affections in lawfull delights, more especially respected Ladies: The La: Katherine Countesse of Huntingdon, and the La: Margaret Countesse of Cumberland, and vnto Sr. Francis Hastinges, and Sr: Tho: Smith, honorable christians & Knights. Tho: Sauile wisheth a continuall practise of their knowledge in the misterie of reconciliation, vntill they be compacted into the Mrs. building, and Really vnited vnto Christ, that finally they may be where he is, and haue their ioy full:
div.p:
MOST Honorable LLa: & you worthily regarded Knights, if I did know any creatures cōparable vnto your selues, for Christian cariage and profession of Religion in the like measure, vnto those surely I would direct this my poore labor & publish their examples, whereby I might direct others as by that star to the wisemen to take view of such shining lights as should beget a desire in the beholders, • o be cōformed the • vnto, euen to find the babe and glorifie the euerlasting God, who inhabiteth Mat. 1. the heauens in neuer ending glory: Besides this it may not bedenyed, but your honors fauors of diuers sorts afforded vnto me both in prison and abroad, haue iustly deserued the deepest offices of all my acknowledgments: And since the Lord hath pleased so to shake all my outward indowments as nothing therin may be found accepable to present in grati animi memoriam, yet let it please you that I offer a pos • e of such fragrant flowers, as I gathered in the Lords own spiritual garden of my most happy changes, amōgst which that same very censure of wisedom hath my thinkes a wonderfull soueraigne wisdom. 3. taste, for diuerting all infections of that contagious discontentment which doth accompany mortalitie in all men. They seeme forsaken (saith he) but their hope is full of immortalit • e: What is that? The next wordes explaine, in few thinges they bee restrained: But in many things they be rewarded: if your Ho: LLa: and you Christian Knights please, to search by way of meditation, why man was
Crea 〈…〉 you wil readl • y d • scouer, out of your owne dayly exercises, the cause and end of mans creaton: was to giue obedience vnto the euer •• uing God their Creator.

The gentle long suffring preseruer of heauen and earth. Ifly vnto thee for thi very gentleues (saith a father) to bee intrated: But how Chris • st. shall they serue him without knowledge of his name? They erred: saith the Lord because they did not know my waies, And how shall this Psal 95: knowledge come, but fy Faith? and how Faith but by the worde preached? And how know they this faith, but by experience? And Rom. 50. 1 Pet. 6. 7. Ro: 5. 4 how commeth experience but by triall, and how triall but by afflictions. Tribulation saith Thapostle worketh patience and patience bops, &c. So that affliction is as the schoole or Academy, wherin the best schollers (by rendering & exercises) be appointed and prepared to Thes. 3. comencements of the dietie, by making familiar their receiued former rudiments of ordinarie discipline and changes. Now how distasing this in vnto ye world, who regorge pleasures & profits, till they sursit, it (killeth not: Christ saith vnto Iohn his Disciples. The poore reciue the Gospell, which worde (Poore) in that place I thinke doth Mat: 11. 29. Isaiah. 61. 1. signifie the meanest sort in estate and knowledge because I find opposition in that Chapter verse 25. I thanke thee O father, that thou hast hid these thinges from the wise and prudent, and hast opened them vnto Babes: Heere seemeth a double warrant to cleere all doubts that the Gospell at it is in it selfe Sermo crucis, so affliction by weyned estate, doth most surely accompany the professors thereof, according to the measure of their desire to be changed, and the Lords purpose to shine in them: But what if the world (for all theise) doe scorne so open truth? Then do I answere, that the Iewes disputed Ioh. 7. 4. euen so, when they said, Why doe none of the rulers beleeue in him. Then which there was neuer any thing more grose and insulse: For Ioh. 12. 42. 43. the worde it selfe giueth a reason of their forsaking him (Viz) For feare to loose their places in the Sinagogue. And also because they loued the praise of men more then the praise of God. Thus hauing cleared in short, as by way of abstract, or post-script the crown of affliction by so plaine and open demonstration, of the sacred W • rde, Ioh. 12. 48. which shall iudge at the last day, I do dedicate this poore exercise
out of my very loue, and for a seriuice vnto you haue personages who are able to discerne the truth of that I write: wherein I offer as a motiue for all men to indure: my owne particular suffrings openly and causelessely orphaned with my many Children by violence inflicted, euen so far as if the worlde had no other president of the Lordes watch ouer his vine. (Behold saith Isaiah, I the Lord doe watch ouer my vine, yea day and night do I watch least any man assaile it,) yet that the Lord hath preserued and fed my most vnworthy selfe, thiese many yeeres as by Rauens, by your respected LLa: mirrours of Religion and vertue, and by that euer renowmed worthy one, the La: Anne Countesse of Warwick, as Pharoahs daughters taken me out of the Reade Arke of my Mother sinne, and putting me to Nurse into the schoole of afflictions and grace. This I Exo. 2. say may remaine as a monument for euer to openly announce the truth of his name in that hee is called wonderfull.

closer.signed: An afflicted seruant of her late most sacred Maiestie Queene Elizabeth. Tho: Sauile,
